properties.name: Hartford Courant, 1986-87
properties.description: Posted by Swo343a285 Broad St., Hartford, CT 06115I left the Portland Business Journal abruptly and ended up quite unexpectedly in Hartford in 1986. It\'s a long story. Suffice it to say it involved a Business Journals chairman who consulted a psychic, a Lear jet, people in dark suits, a corporate spy and a briefcase pitched surreptitiously into the Willamette River. As Dave Barry would say, I am not making this up. At any rate, I applied to The Oregonian for a job. The HR department called up one of my references, the former managing editor of The Kansas City Star and, by then, executive editor of the Hartford Courant. He called me up and told me he needed a business editor. A month later, I was in Hartford.

properties.name: Kansas City Business Journal, 1982-83
properties.description: Posted by Swo343a1100 Main St., Kansas City, MO 64105-5123I was recruited away from The Kansas City Star to this start-up weekly business newspaper. No one was more surprised than we were as the scrappy little paper grew into the flagship for American City Business Journals, "the nation\'s largest publisher of metropolitan business newspapers," according to the company\'s current Web site.

properties.name: Portland Business Journal, 1984-86
properties.description: Posted by Swo343a123 NE Third Ave., Portland, OR 97232At the ripe old age of 31, I was founding editor and later general manager. I arrived in Portland from Kansas City with my family on Jan. 1, 1984. We had a paper on the street on March 5, 1984, and 11,000 paid subscribers a year later. Portland was the fourth paper in the American City Business Journals chain. My lunatic bosses (see Hartford Courant entry) back in Kansas City once threatened to fire me as editor for my bad attitude. Instead, I quit on the spot. The next day, they hired me back and promoted me to general manager. Go figure. I was generally clueless as a general manager, but I treated the sales staff to terrific weekly sales meetings at a local bar. During my last year, we launched the weekly Peanut Butter & Jam concerts in Pioneer Courthouse Square. Our administrative assistant, Sue Magnuson, came up with that great name.

properties.name: San Francisco Business Times, 1987-88
properties.description: Posted by Swo343a275 Battery St., San Francisco, CA 94111 After discovering that I was not an East Coast kind of guy, I fled back to the West Coast to rejoin the editor who had recruited me to start the Kansas City Business Journal. By this time, he had left the American City Business Journals chain to start his own business weekly in San Francisco. I edited the paper for a year until he ran out of money. Then I headed back to my beloved Pacific Northwest and a job at The Oregonian. The Business Journals chain has since added the San Francisco paper to its empire.

properties.name: The Kansas City Star, 1979-82
properties.description: Posted by Swo343a1729 Grand Blvd., Kansas City, MO 64108My first job with a major metropolitan daily newspaper. As a cub reporter, I covered the north suburban area, city hall, and science and medicine.

properties.name: The Oregonian, 1988-present
properties.description: Posted by Swo343a1320 Southwest Broadway, Portland, OR, 97201I\'ve been here since 1988. I\'ve been an assistant city editor, business editor, business reporter, health care reporter, technology reporter and now feature writer in the Living section. My emphasis is on personal technology. Let it be known that feature writing is simply the best job in the known universe.

properties.name: University of Missouri School of Journalism, 1977-79
properties.description: Posted by Swo343a Columbia, MO 65211-1200I got my master\'s degree in journalism here. It\'s one of the all-time great schools of journalism.

properties.name: University of Missouri Washington Program, 1978-79
properties.description: Posted by Swo343a529 14th Street Northwest, Washington, DC 20045Through the university\'s news service, I worked as a Washington correspondent for the Columbia Missourian, the Brattleboro (Vt.) Reformer, the Fredericksburg (Va.) Free Lance-Star, the Easton (Pa.) Express-Times and the Ames (Iowa) Tribune.

properties.name: Wayne Chronicle, 1971-72
properties.description: Posted by Swo343a39.850743, -84.127608My first paying job, in my hometown, Huber Heights, Ohio (known, in all seriousness, as "America\'s largest community of all-brick homes"). The weekly Chronicle no longer exists.

properties.name: Wayne High School Charisma, 1970-71
properties.description: Posted by Swo343a 5400 Chambersburg Road, Huber Heights, OH 45424The school paper was actually called the Drumbeat for its entire history, except for the year we long-haired radicals took over the paper and changed its name to Charisma. Charisma??? What were we thinking?
